hints_html:
This is a special case of integration by parts.

Make \(\displaystyle u=\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\) and \(\displaystyle dv = dx\).

Don’t forget your constant!
hints_latex: This is a special case of integration by parts.
hints_raw:
This is a special case of integration by parts.
Make <math> \displaystyle u=\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) </math> and <math> \displaystyle dv = dx</math>.
Don't forget your constant!
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
Proceeding as in the hint, let \(\displaystyle u=\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\) and \(\displaystyle dv = dx\). Then via the chain rule, we have \(\displaystyle du = \frac{\tfrac{-1}{x^2}}{\tfrac{1}{x^2} + 1} = \frac{-1}{x^2+1}\) and \(\displaystyle v=x\) so integrating by parts gives us

\[\begin{aligned} I_b &= \int \arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\,dx \\ &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) -\int \frac{-x}{x^2+1}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

Now let \(\displaystyle w = x^2+1\) so that \(\displaystyle dw = 2x \ dx\) and thus the above becomes after substitution

\[\begin{aligned} I_b &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) +\int \frac{x}{x^2+1}\,dx\\ &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \int \frac{dw}{2w}\\ &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|w| + C\\ &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|x^2+1| + C\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Proceeding as in the hint, let
$\displaystyle u=\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)$ and
$\displaystyle dv = dx$. Then via the chain rule, we have
$\displaystyle du = \frac{\tfrac{-1}{x^2}}{\tfrac{1}{x^2} + 1} = \frac{-1}{x^2+1}$
and $\displaystyle v=x$ so integrating by parts gives us

\begin{align*}
I_b &=  \int \arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\,dx \\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) -\int \frac{-x}{x^2+1}\,dx
\end{align*}

Now let $\displaystyle w = x^2+1$ so that $\displaystyle dw = 2x \ dx$
and thus the above becomes after substitution

\begin{align*}
I_b &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) +\int \frac{x}{x^2+1}\,dx\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \int \frac{dw}{2w}\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|w| + C\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|x^2+1| + C
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Proceeding as in the hint, let <math> \displaystyle u=\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) </math> and <math> \displaystyle dv = dx</math>. Then via the chain rule, we have <math> \displaystyle du = \frac{\tfrac{-1}{x^2}}{\tfrac{1}{x^2} + 1} = \frac{-1}{x^2+1}</math> and <math> \displaystyle v=x </math> so integrating by parts gives us

<math> 
\begin{align}
I_b &=  \int \arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\,dx \\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) -\int \frac{-x}{x^2+1}\,dx
\end{align}
</math>

Now let <math> \displaystyle w = x^2+1</math> so that <math> \displaystyle dw = 2x \ dx</math> and thus the above becomes after substitution

<math> 
\begin{align}
I_b &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) +\int \frac{x}{x^2+1}\,dx\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \int \frac{dw}{2w}\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|w| + C\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|x^2+1| + C
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Integration: Short Answer Problems - Evaluate the following integrals: state if a definite integral does not exist; use limits for improper integrals. (full marks for correct answer; work must be shown for partial marks)

\(\displaystyle I_b = \int \arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\,dx\)
